Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Full Color, Low Power, Fast-Response, Reflective Display Technology
Award.AbstractNarration:
Modern displays have become the most prevalent portals for information processing and distribution and most of the information we consume is channeled visually through displays of various forms and sizes. Colorful, high-contrast, sunlight readable, and power efficient electrophoretic displays will further close the digital divide between paper and electronic displays. Unfortunately, amalgams of these requirements are the key technical challenges faced by modern display technologies. The proposed new display technology is capable of overcoming these inherent problems to display content in a manner similar to print on paper. Consumers will benefit from the colorful, dynamic display alternative as it causes much lower eyestrain when compared to bright LCDs. The ramifications of such technological advancement are dramatic. The age of digitally dynamic signage may soon be upon us and power consumption efficiency is a key factor in making 'print on paper' a thing of the past. Colored electrophoretic displays consume 54% less energy when compared to conventional LCD?s. In conjunction with energy savings, this technology also reduces the amount of paper consumed, and therefore the environmental benefit of saving trees.

This team has proposed a novel particle-based, low power, colored, reflective and fast response display technology that can be used in ambient lighting conditions. The proposed display platform is enabled by electric-field driven particle suspensions, which offers fast response times capable of displaying colorful images and video. This approach evades many technical issues faced by current electrophoretic methodologies, and scalable to large area displays. Due to its facile fabrication needs, the proposed display geometry could be fabricated by roll-to-roll processing techniques resulting in substantial cost savings. This team's technological advancement uses existing manufacturing techniques and uses 80% less material by volume than conventional displays making it economical and sustainable. Because of this technology's remarkably low power consumption, its applications extend to products as small as key fobs and as large as camouflaged tanks. Considering these merits this team envisions that its low power, color based, particle-driven display technology finds application and increases the value of existing products, while making them sustainable and more enjoyable for consumers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The UM team underwent training at the NSF I-Corps program (April 2015 cohort) wherein we conducted extensive market research and developed ecosystem maps for different customer segments by talking to a large number of potential customers (more than 100), experts, product engineers and consultants in the relevant sectors. These include the electronic signage markets, consumer electronics, advertising, hospitality and the automotive segment. Our original market segments are in low-power colored displays for mobile devices and electronic signage. After many weeks of interviewing, we had a pivot point when we started to talk to the automobile companies and supplies (there happen to be many of them in Michigan). We made a “Go” decision by pursuing an alternation of our patent-pending technology, which is to develop transparent displays for automobile Heads UP Display (HUDs) applications.

 During our customer discovery process, we interviewed potential customers in various market segments that utilize displays in one form or another (consumer electronics, digital signage, automotive, military applications). This process informed us that all displays are compromised devices and customers pick their compromises based on their desired product specification.  By interviewing customers and suppliers about their pains with existing technology, we found out that a transparent display that integrates with the car windshield is a need based requirement for which existing solutions do not exist. Discussions with automotive product development managers and technology strategists, who are dissatisfied with existing solutions, have informed and advanced the design of our transparent display. We can provide automotive component suppliers and OEM’s a transparent, light- scattering, HUD solution that seamlessly integrates with their existing components and overcomes the constraints faced by existing HUD solutions that are available in the market. The key requirements for this kind of display are stringent: extreme transparency (>90%), space constraints, wide field of view (FOV), refresh cycle (<100ms), eye-box (>5in x 6in), contrast ratio (1.5:1) and readability in ambient lighting conditions .Through our initial market research, we have also identified many low specification and low-tolerance to risk markets like digital signage and military application that we will be serving on our progressive path towards automotive HUD’s.
